reviewText:
TL;DR

Feelings Adrift is a great game if you're looking for cheap jump scares, but that's honestly all it is.



The visuals are awesome, at least where the level designs are concerned, but everything is uninspired. The gameplay of each attraction is just a watered down version of other horror games and the sound/music used is taken right out of other games and films. The AI is random and unintelligent, seeming to have no line of sight, and only catch you when you're right next to them. The worst thing to me is not the excessive use of jump scares (which is ALL the time), but the ugly enemy designs. They look so cheap and fake that it's hard to be afraid of them. The game has some cool elements and I like the concept, but I really can't recommend it unless you really like bad jump scares.

I have only played the first level black hole so thats the one I will write about.
The first maze level is a mess. I must have spent over 20 min just to find the coins since I got completely lost because everything looks identical.
The jumpscares are good aswell the music. However the music stops and is quiet for a long time until you enter the next area. The puzzles are ok. The dungeon stage was good and suspensfull.
I will write about the other 2 levels later but for now this game is not recomended.

reviewText: Disclaimer: I've played one of the three currently available attractions."\n\nI really like the idea behind this game. You're at an amusement park and each "attraction" is a mini-game of sorts. The developer has done a decent job of keeping the game updated
date: so I can only imagine how big this game could end up getting. I do feel like it would've benefited as being an Early Access title rather than getting a full release with only a few of these mini games to play
recommended: but at least it's still relatively cheap.\n\nSo far what I've seen is a lot of cheap jump scares. It's nice to see that in a game that's also pretty and has great atmosphere
hoursPlayed: no one seems to be doing those cheap jump scares anymore unless it's a 2D platformer or something. And the fact that the developer can create multiple different atmospheres you can jump between is pretty damn cool. But don't expect this game to be a psychological horror game
helpfulPercent: it's more of a thriller. There are a few puzzles too
votesTotal: but they weren't necessarily intensly difficult either.\n\nAlso I should point out again that this game is GORGEOUS. The dev built this on Unreal 4 and it really makes this game pop. The engine really helped with making the atmospheres feel believable if at times disjointed
votesFunny: at least in Black Hole. The audio was great
commentsCount: although I had trouble with music stopping sometimes if I left the area and then there would be no sound. Some of the effects for the scary portions are so strange that they're scary because you don't know what the hell they are...and for me that's good
column16: but it may not work for you.\n\nWould I recommend you buy this now? Probably not. Would I recommend you buy this when more attractions are available? Probably. And maybe even then buy it on sale. It currently costs $8 and it's a little steep for maybe 3-4 hours of playtime
column17: but of course there will be more later. Give it a try though
column18: you might be surprised.\n\nThis is my first look at the game

reviewText:
EDIT: After thinking a bit more about the game and putting a bit more time into it, I found that it doesn't branch off of what it initially starts with. The entire game is jumpscares (Cheap ones, at that), and the audio doesn't make sense in several areas of the game. Overall, it's not worth $7. It might be worth $1 or $2. If you think you might want it, you can see the Let's Play down below for the basic gameplay it has to offer.

ORIGINAL:
I haven't played much of this game (as you can see) but it's definitely appealing for some reasons:

1) The level design is colorful, strange, and well executed
2) Yes, every scare I've encountered has been a jump scare, but those get me. And I like them :P
3) While it does cost money, it's cheap, and it seems to have a good bit of content for just an average indie horror game"

If you want to see some of the game before you play it
date: I made a YouTube video of it. Check it out if you want:\nhttps://youtu.be/kosge6MG5Hg"

reviewText:
I made a more in-depth review here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qdTKcMB0ycw

Is it worth the money? I don't think so. I would maybe pay $2-3 for it in it's current state, but definitely not $7.

Graphics: 5/10 - It looks ok, but there is a lot of screen tearing when turning and some of it just looks out of place as well.

Sound: 5/10 - Some of it sounds very good, but again, some of it is just very out of place.

Gameplay: 3/10 - Not very good. It's basically a game with multiple mini-games; a FNAF spinoff, a few puzzles, and a tour of a hospital. But what really hurts this score is the broken english in all of the directions, which just makes it hard to understand the objectives of each mode.

Atmosphere: 5/10 - There are some moments when I would actually feel scared, but after a little while I was completely aware of when something was going to happen.

Scares: 2/10 - Just not scary after the first few jumpscares, and that is all the game has to offer.

reviewText:
Is it all jumpscares? Yes.
Do they work on me? Yes.
Did I enjoy the game? Yes.

The game has a cool concept, as you go through each attraction as if it were a Haunted House" type of attraction. They are all disconnected from eachother
date:
and there is no story line. Each one has fresh scares and I found the game to be fun. Think of going to a theme park full of haunted houses.

Why the negative review then!?

I liked Dark Room and Black Hole
recommended: but Terror in the Hospitol is GOD AWFUL. The puzzle is so broken. You need to do 5 steps
hoursPlayed: then repeat the process 3 times. The problem is that with the coins system
